page.title: 03Local History Of Congresbury
page.content:
In 1085 the Manor of Congresbury was held directly by the King. In 1066 it had been held by Earl Harold. It paid tax for 20 hides (about 2400 acres) and was worth 60 shillings. It seems that the area was always used for pasture since it had 250 acres of meadow and pasture 2 leagues long (3 miles) and a half a league (1.5 miles) wide. This supported 2 cobs, 20 cattle, 40 pigs, 200 sheep and 40 goats. Today there is much more cattle raising than sheep rearing.
The Domesday Book tells us that the manor paid Â£28 15s in white silver. This is lead and although there are remains of lead mines on the nearby Mendips, there are none near Congresbury.
